abstract.p: Unconditional pricing models fail to support a positive risk–return trade-off. When excess market return is negative an inverse relationship between the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) beta and equal-weighted and value-weighted portfolio return is observed. To accommodate market movement in the pricing model, two volatility regimes (high/low) is delineated by specifying a threshold on conditional market volatility estimated via a generalised autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (GARCH) process. In the low volatility regime, the CAPM beta risk premium and the downside beta risk premium are negative. This observation is robust to the level of the threshold used and is more pronounced in value-weighted portfolios. When the market condition and market movement is incorporated together as conditioning variables, a strong relationship between CAPM beta and return is uncovered.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Capital asset pricing has always been an active area of research in finance. The basic capital asset pricing model (CAPM) is a single factor model of the risk–return relationship and is widely used in capital budgeting. The CAPM of Sharpe (1964) relates the expected return of any capital asset to the measure of its systematic risk referred to as the beta. In the context of the CAPM, the beta is the only relevant risk measure and expected return is expressed as the sum of the return on a riskless asset (risk-free rate) and a premium for the beta risk.

In the past four decades, many studies extensively investigated the validity of the CAPM and reported mixed results. For example, Lintner (1965) observes a significant positive relationship between risk and return. However, Lintner (1965) reveals that the residual variance is also priced, thereby questioning the empirical validity of the CAPM. Black et al. (1972) corroborate the findings of Lintner (1965) in as far as a positive relationship between risk and return is concerned. Fama and MacBeth (1973) fail to reject the hypothesis of a positive linear relationship between average return and beta. All these studies investigate US data prior to 1970. Moreover, the CAPM beta estimated in the market model is claimed to be biased downward due to infrequent and non-synchronous trading (Berglund et al. 1989; Cohen et al. 1978; Dimson 1979; Scholes and Williams 1977). Lakonishok and Saphiro (1986) reveal a significant relationship between market capitalisation (firm size) and return and that the beta risk–return relationship is insignificant. It is argued that, generally, beta lacks efficiency and completeness as a measure of risk. Fama and French (1992) reveal that the relation between the beta and return is flat and the size variable is significant with or without the CAPM beta. They report that book-to-market ratio is even more powerful than size as an explanatory variable of variation in the return. They argue that the positive association between return and beta as predicted by the CAPM might have vanished in recent times, a notion supported by Chan and Lakonishok (1993).

Pettengill et al. (1995) provide empirical evidence that when excess market return is negative an inverse relationship between the beta and portfolio returns is plausible. Acknowledging this relationship, they find a significant linear relationship between CAPM beta and returns. Hence, they argue that a reason for inconclusive evidence in the previous studies may be the failure to accommodate market movements in the analysis. However, the strength of the beta risk–return relation conditional on market movement may vary with the criterion used in the classification of up/down markets (Crombez and Vennet 2000).

Galagedera and Faff (2005) investigate whether the risk–return relation varies depending on changing market movement reflected in the volatility of returns. They define three market volatility regimes and examine empirical validity of a three-beta pricing model. In a crosssectional framework, Galagedera and Faff (2005) find that the beta risk premium in the three market volatility regimes is priced when the pricing model accommodates up/down market conditions.

According to the CAPM, a stock’s expected excess return is proportional to its market beta and is assumed constant across up and down markets. Factor models like the Fama and French’s (1993) three-factor model implies that factor loadings across up and down markets are symmetric. However, it is argued that investors may care differently about downside risk than they care about total risk (Markowitz 1959). Markowitz suggests constructing portfolios based on semi-variance rather than on the variance. Semi-variance measures dispersion in the returns below a threshold or a target rate of return and thereby treats upside risk (gains) differently from downside risk (losses). If investors dislike downside risk, then they ought to demand high compensation in the form of higher expected returns for holding assets with greater downside risk. One natural extension of the CAPM that takes into account this asymmetric treatment of risk is the use of downside and upside betas (Bawa and Lindenberg 1977). The downside beta is the market beta computed over periods for which the market return is below a minimum acceptable return. As far as we are aware, no study investigates conditional pricing models in a downside framework. We aim to fill this void.

This article investigates unconditional and conditional risk–return models specified under the downside framework and under the conventional framework. We test the empirical validity of these models using portfolios constructed from a sample of stocks in the Indonesian stock market. Indonesia is an emerging market and therefore, thin trading is a concern. We make a correction for any bias that may creep in due to less frequently traded stocks in the data. Several variants of the risk–return models are also considered to examine the possibility of a non-linear relationship and concern about asymmetry in the return. The conditional models are developed by accommodating (a) market condition captured by negative and positive excess return and (b) movement in the market captured by conditional volatility in the return. We chose to test these models in the Indonesian market since increasing global investment flows into Indonesia provide a formidable challenge to equity evaluation due to considerable variation in market condition and movement.

The unconditional models fail to uncover the risk–return relationship in the cross-section. However, when the risk–return relation is conditional on market condition (up/down), a significant positive (negative) relationship between the CAPM beta and portfolio returns is observed in the up (down) market. To accommodate market movement in the pricing models two volatility regimes based on the level of conditional volatility of market returns is specified. When market movement (up/down) and market volatility are incorporated together as conditioning variables, the beta risk premium is significant and positive in the up market and negative in the down market. These observations suggest that beta as a reliable asset allocation tool appears to depend on the ability of investors to anticipate potential movement in equity markets. Inclusion of factors, such as, squared systematic risk, residual variance and skewness, generally do not provide additional explanatory power of variation in the returns in the cross-section.

In the following section, we discuss modelling of market condition and market volatility in the risk–return relationship in the conventional and downside frameworks. The third section describes the data. The method used to test the relationship between risk and return is described in the fourth section. The fifth section reports empirical results and provides a discussion. The sixth section concludes the article.

sec.title: Modelling Market Condition
sec.p: Market condition is defined according to whether or not the market return exceeds a pre-specified threshold. The up (down) market corresponds to the days in which the market return exceeds (falls below) the threshold. Studies have used different thresholds. For example, Kim and Zumwalt (1979) use the average monthly market return, the average risk-free rate and zero as thresholds. Crombez and Vennet (2000) define up/down market based on whether the monthly market return is larger or smaller than zero and whether the market return is larger or smaller than the return on a risk-free investment. We classify a given day as an up (down) market day when the market return in excess of the risk-free rate is positive (non-positive).
where Rmt is market return in excess of the risk-free rate in day t. Then, δ = 1 in up market days and δ = 0 in down market days.

sec.title: Modelling Market Movement
sec.p: We capture market movement through volatility in the market returns. First, we fit a volatility model for daily market returns and obtain estimates of conditional variance σt2. Then, based on the magnitude of these volatility estimates, we classify each observation day into one of the two market volatility regimes: high and low.

where σx* is the xth percentile of the estimated conditional variance series, {σ^t2}. We consider three values of x: 50, 75 and 90 corresponding to the median, the third quartile and the 90th percentile, respectively, of {σ^t2}. The indicator function θ is used to partition observation days into two groups: days with low (θ = 0) market volatility and days with high (θ = 1) market volatility.

sec.title: Models Considered Under the Conventional Framework
sec.p:
In this section, we present the pricing models investigated under the conventional framework. The market model and its variants fall under this category. In empirical investigations of the CAPM, the beta is estimated using the market model given as:
(3) Rit = αi + βi Rmt + νit,

where Rit is return of portfolio i in excess of the risk-free rate in day t and vit is a random error term assumed to be independent and identically distributed. The slope coefficient βi estimates the beta of portfolio i. The beta estimated using the method of ordinary least squares for less frequently traded stocks are likely to be downward biased as the returns of these stocks are not perfectly synchronised with the market returns (Dimson 1979; Scholes and Williams 1977). Dimson (1979) reviews several alternatives for correcting this bias. In this study, the aggregating beta procedure proposed in Dimson (1979) with two lags and two leads is adopted. Then the market model may be modified as follows:
(4) Rit=αi+βi−2Rm,t−2+βi−1Rm,t−1+βiRmt+βi+1Rm,t+1+βi+2Rm,t+2+uit

to obtain a bias corrected beta βiDIM such that
(5) βiDIM=βi−2+βi−1+βi+βi+1+βi+2.
The models given in Equations (3) and (4) are time series models.

sec.title: Unconditional Models
sec.p: Fama and MacBeth (1973) employ CAPM beta, squared CAPM beta and residual variance as factors that may explain the cross-sectional variation in expected returns. It is also of interest to test whether the investors are concerned about asymmetry in the return distribution as well. Cooley et al. (1977) argue that skewness provides distinct and useful information apart from the CAPM beta. Menezes et al. (1980) argue that skewness may capture downside risk. Usually, to test the empirical validity of the CAPM, the following cross-sectional model is estimated.

where σ2 is the variance of the residuals and β is the slope coefficient estimated in the market model given in Equation (3) and SK is the skewness in the distribution of portfolio returns. From Equations (6) and (7), several testable implications of the CAPM can be derived. The fundamental CAPM hypothesis is that the risk premium of beta is positive. This can be tested using the null hypothesis H0:γ¯2=0 against the alternative H1:γ¯1>0 where γ¯1 is the average risk premium associated with the CAPM beta estimated in the cross-sectional regressions. The CAPM implies that the risk–return relation is linear. This can be tested with H0:γ¯2=0 against H1:γ¯2≠0, where γ¯2 is the average of γ2testimated in the cross-sectional regression (Equation [7]). In the CAPM context, beta is the only relevant risk and the asset specific risk may be diversified away. This may be tested with H0:γ¯3=0 against H1:γ¯3≠0. Similarly, the premium associated with skewness in Equation (7) can be used to test whether or not, in making investment decisions, the investors consider the return distribution as symmetric. Scott and Horvath (1980) argue that investors dislike even moments in preference to the odd moments such as skewness. The movements in the right tail of the return distribution are considered beneficial to the investors so that an increase in skewness implies expectation of a smaller premium. This argument specifies a negative sign for the coefficient of the skewness in Equation (7). That can be tested with H0:γ¯4=0 against H0:γ¯4>0. The Sharp–Lintner version of the CAPM also implies that the asset uncorrelated with the market has expected return equal to the risk-free rate. Then the intercepts in Equations (6) and (7) are expected to be zero. This is tested with H0:γ¯0=0 against a two-sided alternative. The tests carried out with the parameters estimated in model (7) are also repeated with the following model where the CAPM beta is replaced by the Dimson beta.
where σiDIM2 is the variance of the residuals estimated in Equation (4).

sec.title: Conditional Models—Based on Market Condition
sec.p:
In this section, we describe pricing models that incorporate market conditions. Following Pettengill et al. (1995), we incorporate market condition in models (6)–(8) as follows:
(9) Rit=δγ0tU+(1−δ)γ0tD+γ1tUδβi+γ1tD(1−δ)βi+εit,
(10) Rit=δγ0tU+(1−δ)γ0tD+γ1tUδβi+γ1tD(1−δ)βi+γ2tUδβi2+ γ2tD(1−δ)βi2+γ3tUδσi2+γ3tD(1−δ)σi2+γ4tUδSKi+ γ4tD(1−δ)SKi+εit
(11) Rit=δγ0tU+(1−δ)γ0tD+γ1tUδβiDIM+γ1tD(1−δ)βiDIM+ γ2tUδβiDIM2 + γ2tD(1−δ)βiDIM2+γ3tUδ σiDIM2+ γ3tD(1−δ)σiDIM2+γ4tDδSKi+ γ4tD(1−δ)SKi+εit.

The foregoing models are estimated in each observation interval (each day) of the testing period. When the market return is lower than the risk-free rate, we hypothesise an inverse relationship between risk and return. Since γ1U is estimated in periods with positive excess market returns, the expected sign of this coefficient is positive. Hence the hypothesis tested is H0: γ–U1 against H1: γ–U1 > 0. On the other hand,γ1D is estimated in periods with non-positive excess market returns and the expected sign of this coefficient is negative. Hence the hypothesis tested here is H0:γ¯1D=0 against H0:γ¯1D<0. If the null hypothesis can be rejected in both cases, the results would indicate the existence of a systematic conditional relationship between beta and realised return.

The CAPM implies a linear risk–return relationship. Hence average γ2estimated in Equations (10) and (11) is tested against a two-sided alternative. That is H0:γ¯2U=0 against H1:γ¯2U≠0 and H0:γ¯2D=0 against H1:γ¯2D≠0. Similarly, as in the case with unconditional, models the average risk premium estimates γ3 in models (10) and (11) are also tested against a two-sided alternative assuming that CAPM beta is the only relevant risk measure. The test of hypothesis conducted here are H0:γ¯3U=0 against H1:γ¯3U≠0 and H0:γ¯3D=0 against H1:γ¯3D≠0. Skewness is introduced to test whether or not the investors are concerned about asymmetry in the return distribution. Significance of the premium associated with skewness is tested using H0:γ¯4U=0 against H1:γ¯4U≠0 and H0:γ¯4D=0 against H1:γ¯4D≠0.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Based on Market Volatility
sec.p:
We incorporate the two market volatility regimes in the pricing models by simply replacing δ in Equations (9)–(11) with θ . Now the premium estimated in low (high) volatility regime is denoted with the superscript L (H). The cross-sectional models estimated here are as follows:
(12) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβi+γ1tL(1−θ)βi+εit
(13) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβi+γ1tL(1−θ)βi+ γ2tHθβi2+γ2tL(1−θ)βi2+γ3tHθαi2+γ3tL(1−θ)σi2+ γ4tHθSKi+γ4tL(1−θ)SKi+εit
(14) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβiDIM+γ1tL(1−θ)βiDIM+ γ2tHθβiDIM2+γ2tL(1−θ)βiDIM2+γ3tHθσiDIM2+ γ3tL(1−θ)σiDIM2+γ4tLθSKi+γ4tL(1−θ)SKi+εit,

where i = 1, 2,. .., N and t = 1, 2,. .., T. These relationships are estimated in each observation interval of the testing period. The hypotheses estimated here are similar to those in the unconditional models (6)–(8). In these models, the direction of association between any given explanatory variable and return is hypothesised to have the same association in both high and low market volatility regimes. The aim here is to investigate whether or not the relationship hypothesised in the unconditional model holds in different volatility regimes. The presumed relationship holds only if the null hypothesis is rejected in favour of the alternative in both volatility regimes.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Based on Market Condition and Market Volatility
sec.p:
In this section, we develop pricing models incorporating both the market condition (up/down) and market volatility (high/low). Then four scenarios are possible: up market–high volatility (UH) indicated by δθ , up market–low volatility (UL) indicated by δ (1 – θ), down market–high volatility (DH) indicated by (1 – δ )θ and down market–low volatility (DL) indicated by (1 – δ) (1 – θ). Recall that δ = 1 in the up market and θ = 1 in the high volatility regime. Let δθ , δ (1 – θ), (1 – δ)θ and (1 – δ) (1 – θ) be denoted by K1, K2, K3 and K4, respectively. Then the cross-sectional models estimated here may be given as follows:
(15) Rit=γ0tUHK1+γ0tULK2+γ0tDHK3+γ0tDLK4+γ1tUHK1βi+ γ1tULK2βi+γ1tDHK3βi+γ1tDLK4βi+εit
(16) Rit=γ0tUHK1+γ0tULK2+γ0tDHK3+γ0tDLK4+γ1tUHK1βi+ γ1tULK2βi+γ1tDHK3βi+γ1tDLK4βi+γ2tUHK1βi2+ γ2tULK2βi2+γ2tDHK3βi2+γ2tDLK4βi2+γ3tUHK1σi2+ γ3tULK2σi2+γ3tDHK3σi2+γ3tDLK4σi2+γ4tUHK1σi2+ γ4tULK2SKi+γ4tDHK3SKi+γ4tDLK4SKi+εit
(17) Rit=γ0tUHK1+γ0tULK2+γ0tDHK3+γ0tDLK4+γ1tUHK1βiDIM+ γ1tULK2βiDIM+γ1tDHK3βiDIM+γ1tDLK4βiDIM+ γ2tUHK1βiDIM2+γ2tULK2βiDIM2+γ2tDHK3βiDIM2+ γ2tDLK4βiDIM2+γ3tUHK1σiDIM2+γ3tULK2σiDIM2+ γ3tDHK3σiDIM2+γ3tDLK4σiDIM2+γ4tUHK1σiDIM2+ γ4tULK2SKi+γ4tDHK3SKi+γ4tDLK4SKi+εit

The relationships are estimated in each day of the testing period. In models (9)–(11), we hypothesise that the beta risk premium estimated in the up (down) market is positive (negative). Following the same reasoning, a positive and statistically significant beta risk premium in the up market–high volatility regime and a negative and statistically significant beta risk premium in the down market–high volatility regime are sufficient to suggest a systematic relationship between the beta and return in the high volatility regime. We stipulate hypotheses on the other risk measures in the same way.

sec.title: Models Considered Under the Downside Framework
sec.p:
Bawa and Lindenberg (1977) in their interpretation of the CAPM in a downside framework define a measure of systematic risk in the downside (downside beta) as follows:
(18) βid=E[(Rit)min(Rmt,0)]E[min(Rmt,0)]2

Harlow and Rao (1989) use the mean return as the threshold to define another measure of downside risk that may be expressed as follows:
(19) βiHR=E[(Rit−μi)min(Rmt−μm,0)]E[min(Rmt−μm,0)]2,

where μi and μm are portfolio i and market portfolio mean return, respectively. As aggregation does not apply in the case of Harlow and Rao beta, we use Bawa and Lindenberg beta as the measure of downside risk. See Galagedera and Brooks (2007) for more details on this issue.

sec.title: Unconditional Models
sec.p:
The unconditional models considered under the downside framework are as follows:
(20) Rit=γ0t+γ0tβid+εit,
(21) Rit=γ0t+γ1tβid+γ2tSK+εit,
(22) Rit=γ0t+γ1tβid+γ2tβi+εit,
(23) Rit=γ0t+γ1tβid+γ2tβi+γ3tσid2+γ4tSKi+εit,
where σid2 is the variance in the residuals estimated in the downside market model defined as Rit=αi+βidmin(Rmt,0)+vit. We estimate downside risk βid Z βid using Equation (18).

The pricing model given in Equation (20) is analogous to the one given in Equation (6) which is the basic cross-sectional model under the conventional framework. We augment this model with skewness to investigate whether any residual variation in the returns not explained by downside beta is associated with a measure of asymmetry in the portfolio return distribution. In model (22), CAPM beta is included along with downside beta so that we may investigate whether CAPM beta and downside beta complement each other or not. In model (23), we investigate the explanatory power of downside beta and CAPM beta after controlling for skewness and downside idiosyncratic risk σid2. The derivation of testable implications here is similar to those outlined for unconditional models under the conventional framework in the section ‘Unconditional Models’.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Based on Market Volatility
sec.p:
We do not consider cross-sectional risk–return relationship models based on up/down market condition in the downside framework, because the pricing models under the downside framework are derived under a specified market condition. Hence, the conditional models we consider here accommodate only the market movement as measured in conditional volatility. The models considered here are as follows:
(24) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβid+γ1tL(1−θ)βid+εit,
(25) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβid+γ1tL(1−θ)βid+ γ2tHθβi+γ2tL(1−θ)βi+εit,
(26) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβid+ γ1tL(1−θ)βid+ γ2tHθβi+ γ2tL(1−θ)βi+γ3tHθσid2+γ3tL(1−θ)σid2+εit,
(27) Rit=θγ0tH+(1−θ)γ0tL+γ1tHθβid+γ1tL(1−θ)βid+ γ2tHθSKi+γ2tL(1−θ)SKi+εit.

We hypothesise that investors expect a premium to accept variation in the low volatility regime as well as in the high volatility regime of the market. This means that we expect the CAPM beta risk premium and downside risk premium to be positive. Our aim is to investigate the same risk–return relationships considered in the ‘Unconditional Models’ section under high and low volatility regimes. The testable implications here are similar to those outlined in ‘Conditional Models—Based on Market Volatility’ section.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: Data employed in this study includes daily returns on 316 stocks traded on the Indonesian Stock Exchange (formerly Jakarta Stock Exchange, JSX), in the period 1 January 1996 to 31 December 2006. The 316 stocks account for about 90 per cent of market capitalisation. The daily returns are computed assuming continuous compounding of returns. We use the JSX Composite Index as a proxy for the market portfolio and SBI (Interest rate of Bank Indonesia) as a proxy for the risk-free rate. The sample period spans over 2,550 observation days.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: The investigation is carried out with two types of portfolios: CAPM beta portfolios and downside beta portfolios. The CAPM beta and downside beta of each stock is estimated with time series data over the full sample period and using the Equations (3) and (18), respectively. In each case 20 portfolios are formed after ranking stocks on the relevant beta.1 Portfolio return is calculated in two ways: equally weighted and value weighted.

The risk–return relationship is analysed adopting a two-stage procedure. In the first stage of the analysis, for each portfolio, we estimate the factors (explanatory variables) considered in the cross-sectional regressions. In the second stage, the estimated factors are regressed on portfolio returns of the day immediately following the stage one estimation period. This procedure is repeated 2,300 times rolling forward one day at a time.

sec.title: Volatility Model
sec.p: A model that has been used successfully to capture volatility in financial time series is the autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (ARCH) model introduced in the seminal paper by Engle (1982). The ARCH model allows the current conditional variance to be a function of the past squared error terms. This is consistent with volatility clustering. Bollerslev (1986) later generalised the ARCH model (GARCH model) such that the current conditional variance is allowed to be a function of the past conditional variance and past squared error terms. We consider that market returns may be modelled as a GARCH process with mean equation: Rmt = μt and conditional variance equation: σt2=δ0+δ1εt−12+δ2σt−12. This GARCH(1, 1) model is estimated using the maximum likelihood approach for returns in the JSX Composite Index assuming conditional normality in the standardised residuals. All parameters estimated here (μ = 0.001232, δ0 = 0.000006, δ1 = 0.108929, and δ2 = 0.877613) are significantly different from zero at the 1 per cent level.2 The conditional variance estimated in this model is used to classify the observation days into two groups: the low volatility regime and high volatility regime.3

sec.title: Conventional Framework
sec.p: In this section, we discuss the risk premium estimated in the unconditional and conditional pricing models derived under the conventional framework with CAPM beta sorted portfolios.
Hereafter we refer to CAPM beta as beta.

sec.title: Unconditional Models
sec.p: Table 1 gives the risk premium estimated in the unconditional models (6)–(8). Model (6) estimates reveal that there is no significant relation between beta risk and return for equal-weighted portfolios. However, when value-weighted portfolios are used, a negative beta risk–return relationship significant at the 10 per cent level is observed. A similar observation is made in models (7) and (8).4 The premium for squared beta in model (7) is significant at the 5 per cent level with value-weighted portfolios. However, squared Dimson beta is not significant in both equal- and value-weighted portfolios. On the other hand, the premium associated with variance is positive and significant (at the 1 per cent level) in equal-weighted portfolios. The relation between skewness and return is positive and significant at the 5 per cent level irrespective of the type of portfolio used, suggesting that investors may be concerned about asymmetry in the return distribution. A previous study using excess returns of portfolios of stocks traded on the JSX reveals that beta alone cannot explain portfolio excess returns (Febrian and Herwany 2007).

sec.title: Conditional Models—Conditional on Market Condition
sec.p: It is plausible that the foregoing results are biased due to the aggregation of positive and negative excess market return periods. In this section, we discuss the risk–return relation in up and down markets separately. In our sample period, there are 1,171 up market days and 1,129 down market days. The estimated regression coefficients of models (9)–(11) given in Table 2 provide strong support for a conditional relation between beta and realised return. As expected high beta portfolios are associated with lower returns in the down market than low beta portfolios.5

Table 2 also presents premium estimated when beta, squared beta, the residual variance and skewness are employed to explain the crosssectional variation in expected returns. The beta–return relationship estimated in model (10) is similar to the finding in model (9). When Dimson beta is used instead of the beta, the results do not change. In models (10) and (11), skewness is positive and significant. This we observe only in the up market and with equal-weighted portfolios. There is no evidence of nonlinearity in the CAPM beta and return relation. None of the conditional models considered here support a premium for total risk.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Conditional on Market Volatility
sec.p: We demarcate two volatility regimes using three thresholds for their identification. When the median is the threshold, 1,150 high and 1,150 low volatility days are observed. When the third quartile is the threshold, the split becomes 575 high and 1,725 low volatility days. Ninetieth percentile partitions the sample into 230 high and 2,070 low volatility days. The risk premium estimated in pricing models (12)–(14) under all three thresholds are given in Table 3. Table 3 entries reveal that none of the beta risk premium has the hypothesised sign which is positive. Further, there is limited evidence that the premium associated with skewness may be positive and significantly different from zero in the high volatility regime. The inconclusive results observed in the models conditional on market volatility and with different thresholds may be due to not modelling market conditions (Galagedera and Faff 2005). We investigate this in the next section.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Conditional on Market Condition and Market Volatility
sec.p: When modelling market condition and market volatility in the pricing model, we partition sample days into four groups.6 The estimation results of Equations (15)–(16) under the three thresholds are presented in Table 4. In the conditional models considered here, we observe that beta risk premium is significantly different from zero at the 1 per cent level with a positive (negative) risk premium in the up (down) market. The premium for beta squared is also significant with a negative (positive) sign in the up (down) market suggesting that a non-linear relation between the CAPM beta and return may not be ruled out. The skewness premium has no particular pattern to suggest an association with portfolio returns.

sec.title: Downside Framework
sec.p: In this section, we discuss the risk premium estimated in the unconditional and conditional pricing models derived under the downside framework with downside beta sorted portfolios.

sec.title: Unconditional Models
sec.p: The results obtained in the unconditional models (20)–(23) are given in Table 5. In all models, we observe an inverse relation between downside beta and return. When CAPM beta is in the model together with downside beta, there is strong evidence that the risk premium associated with the CAPM beta is positive and significant. These relationships are uncovered with equal-weighted and value-weighted portfolios. When residual variance is included (model [23]) together with downside beta and CAPM beta, the premium of residual variance is not significantly different from zero. Model (21) investigates the cross-sectional relationship between return and downside beta together with skewness. The results of model (21) reveal that the premium for skewness is positive and highly significant under both weighting schemes.

sec.title: Conditional Models—Conditional on Market Volatility
sec.p: Table 6 presents the risk premium estimated in the conditional models (24)–(27). The results reveal that downside beta risk may be priced only in the low volatility regime. This observation is more pronounced when the threshold that delineates the high and low volatility regime is the 3rd quartile and the 90th percentile. On the other hand, the premium for CAPM beta is positive and significant only in the high volatility regime. This we observe when CAPM beta is in the pricing model together with downside beta and in both equal-weighted and value-weighted portfolios. The data did not reveal a positive association between CAPM beta and return conditional on market volatility in model (12). Inclusion of the residual variance (model 26) produces no difference in the results of model (25). Like in model (13), skewness in model (27) appears priced only in the high volatility regime.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: This article analyses unconditional and conditional pricing models using a sample of stocks listed on the Indonesian Stock Exchange. The models are derived under the conventional and downside frameworks and investigated in a set of value-weighted and equal-weighted portfolios. The unconditional models fail to explain the risk–return relation in the cross-section. However, when the market movement (up/down) is incorporated as the conditioning variable, the beta risk premium is significant and positive in the up market and negative in down market. When market movement is modelled in the pricing models with two volatility regimes based on the level of conditional volatility of market returns, the beta risk premium and downside beta risk premium are significantly different from zero in the low volatility regime. However, their signs are opposite to what is expected. In the models under the conventional framework, skewness appears to be priced only in the up market and in the high volatility regime.

fn.p: The first portfolio comprises 12 stocks and each of the other 19 portfolios is made up of 16 stocks.

We did statistical tests to see whether the GARCH(1, 1) model is adequate to model conditional volatility of the JSX Composite Index returns. An ARCH-LM test with five lags on the standardised residuals reveals that additional ARCH is not present in the model.

To check whether the result is robust to the leverage effect, we considered PARCH, EGARCH and APARCH models as well. The correlation between the conditional variance produced by these models and that of the GARCH(1, 1) model is very high. Hence GARCH(1, 1) being parsimonious we use the conditional variance estimated in the GARCH(1, 1) specification.
The CAPM beta and Dimson beta are highly positively correlated (0.95).
Lam (2001) observes that the premium for CAPM beta risk estimated in the up market is high compared to that in the down market.

When the sample period is partitioned with median (third quartile and ninetieth percentile) as volatility threshold; 545 up market–high volatility days (257 and 108), 626 up market–low volatility days (914 and 1063), 605 down market–high volatility days (318 and 122) and 524 down market–low volatility days (811 and 1007) are observed.
